Comment: I am playing with Black against a stronger player. As usual, I play the Sicilian Defence.

White avoids the main lines. This is a move that is still quite common.

White avoids the main lines. This is a move that is still quite common.
Other possible moves are 3...Bd7 and 3...Nd7.
White gives up the bishop pair and Black is left with doubled pawns.
I am happy to play this position. The doubled pawns are not that bad.
A simple developing move. This is not played as often as 5...e5 or 5...Bg4. I think the next move shows why.
A simple developing move. This is not played as often as 5...e5 or 5...Bg4. I think the next move shows why.
White hits the knight and tries to induce dxe5, which leaves Black with isolated doubled pawns.
I rather move the knight than break my pawn structure.
Moving the rook to a better square and renewing the threat of forcing isolated doubled pawns (exd6 and Black cannot recapture with the e-pawn). My position is quite awkward.
I decide to fianchetto the dark-squared bishop.
I do not understand this move. 8. exd6 seems better for White.
Now I can recapture with the e-pawn again.
Opening the diagonal for the bishop.
Developing the other bishop.
Developing the knight first.
The king gets away from the e-file.
The knight is well-placed here. However, 11. Ne4 was also possible, because I cannot capture the e5-pawn without losing the c-pawn and then probably another pawn.
My rook moves to the half-open file. The b-pawn is protected now, but the situation may change later.
Develops the bishop.
I want to play d5, so the knight must move away. 12. Nb6 is also possible.
